shows.title: The 90s melodically dark, punchy rock, pop, alt, and indie. show!
shows.description: Saturday, October 30th, 2021 - the 90s melodically dark, punchy rock, pop, alt, and indie show! There's something about needing to shake the cobwebs off the morning after that just lends itself to this beautifully produced music of the 90s. Thumping drums, throbbing bass lines, and impassioned vocals that are either whispered or screamed it all just sounds good loud. From Bush to the Beastie Boys, Jeff Buckley to The Prodigy, this one should liven things up a bit!

shows.title: The mellow alt/roots/folk rock Americana (350th!) show!
shows.description: Business as usual on the 350th show (297th on MixCloud) and today I was into a more mellow vibe than recent shows, inspired by a T-Bone Burnett song that features on the Stephen King mini-series adaptation Mr Mercedes. Today's show was much more about a vibe than a look at a specific time period so songs appear from the mid-seventies up to present day, but I like to think that if they weren't announced as such, you might not know! Grab a bourbon and some smoked almonds for this one. Make yourself comfortable :)

shows.title: The new music show!
shows.description: On reflection today's show felt like quite a vibrant selection of new music from a variety of artists. Gone are the shoe-gazing, dream-poppy tracks of earlier in the year, and in their place some more stout, determined, punchier tracks across the variety of genres. I thoroughly enjoyed today's show, I hope you did/do too!

shows.title: The selections of soul from in and around 1968 show!
shows.description: Inspiration for these shows comes from all places. Today's was from a song featured on the mini-series adaptation of Stephen King's Mr. Mercedes, Fool For You by The Impressions. That's when I realised I wanted to get into the '68 soul sound very specifically. Nothing academic today, but I did try and go for some of the deeper album cuts over the obvious and arguably overplayed.

shows.title: The early 90s alt rock/pop/folk female vocalist show!
shows.description: Revisiting one of my favourite genres today, but digging deeper into some of the albums that a lot of people I knew owned (including myself). I'm drawn to the production a lot of times with these selections. Clean, almost exclusively acoustic instruments and fairly unmolested vocals. The albums don't have a particularly live sound like the 60s and 70s stuff I love, but the arrangements are simple and the sound is rich and punchy. Sounds good loud!

tracks.title: I Wanna Be Your Joey Ramone

shows.title: The new wave of classic rock show!
shows.description: Today's show is the Tuesday new music show with a little more flexibility in the definition of new. There are many new tracks - some released as recently as a week ago, others up to 6 years ago, but the resuscitation of the genre of melodic rock and AOR is more of the focus today. A favourite of mine through my teenage years, I was surprised recently to discover a band called Station, and then surprised again that they released a new album last week. I was even more surprised to discover there was a new melodic rock, or new wave of classic rock scene that I'd somehow missed beginning sometime around 2014-16. So today's show is an exploration into that!

tracks.title: Show Me What You'd Die For

shows.title: The 1982 UK and US Number Ones show!
shows.description: Today's show is a chronological play-through of number one singles in the UK and US for 1982. I was 2 turning 3 so I don't remember all of them, but it must have been just as I was starting to acknowledge music, because many of them ring with a clarity that can only be the result of a first-write to the brain matter! Tap into the time machine, and take yourself back almost four decades - there's some bangers on here!

tracks.title: Can't Go for That (No Can Do)
Hard to Say I'M Sorry / Get Away
Do You Really Want To Hurt Me

shows.title: The roots rock, rockabilly, swing revival, alternative rock show!
shows.description: Today's show was inspired by a track I heard yesterday by a band called Southern Culture On The Skids - a southern rock, country, rockabilly, psychobilly band from North Carolina formed in the 1980s. This sent me down a swing revival rabbit hole which I was really interested to play out. Unfortunately for live listeners, today's live broadcast was plagued with MixCloud disconnections, but if you're listening again, you'll probably wonder what all the fuss is about!

shows.title: The hard rock power ballads from the 80s and 90s show!
shows.description: I've resisted playing many - if any - power ballads on the show until now, mainly because a lot of them are a little obvious and fairly overplayed. Other more obscure tracks don't tend to fit out of context, so there was only one thing for it: an unashamedly 80s and 90s power ballad show! This show is the sound of my headphones throughout the 90s and the posters on my wall. Warm your voice up and make sure to stretch before rocking out with air drums and guitar! Who wants a mixtape?

shows.title: The Prince love-fest and more show!
shows.description: Following the terrific disappointment of losing power during yesterday's show, I was in the mood for some Prince to pull me out of the funk! Prince is a legend for all of his prolific bad-assery, and today's show is a spotlight on some of the perhaps lesser known tracks he's written, produced, and collaborated on during the 80s and early 90s. Following that catharsis is some power pop/rock/alternative classics to close it out!

tracks.title: Why You Wanna Trip on Me
When the World Is Running Down, You Make the Best of What's Still Around

shows.title: The rock, power pop, psychedelic, freakbeat show!
shows.description: Friday, October 1st, 2021 - the 1960s rock, power pop, psychedelic, freakbeat show! Inspired by a song I heard this morning on a new radio station from my home town in England, today's show is a play-through of some obscure tracks from the era, balanced with some well known tracks, before moving gently into some of the best... oh no, a power cut!⚡️We have survived power cuts before (battery backups), and internet outages (MiFi hotspots), but this time, the MiFi wouldn't connect to the show computer, and the battery backup would have depleted before the end of the show. The last 14 songs and 39 minutes may well always remain a mystery...

shows.title: The 1955 show!
shows.description: Fire up the flux capacitor and let's head back in time to 1955 - a year I know most about from the film Back to The Future. It's also the year Steve Alemi was born, and today is his birthday so the show is a play-through of music written or released in that year. The rumblings of rock and roll rearing its head are present, as are some more traditional pop and jazz influenced songs. Listening through you can really get a sense of how much music is about to change... forever! Happy Birthday Steve! Spread out!

shows.title: The Nashville tuning show!
shows.description: Nashville tuning, or high strung tuning is a great "trick" to add texture and character to a song often by adding it as a doubled track alongside a standard tuned guitar. Sweet, shimmering, and sparkly, it's a cool technique that cuts through the mix and adds a little extra sugar! After being inspired by a video my Dad sent me, I've ordered a couple of sets of strings to setup one of my guitars, and I wanted to explore how this method has been used across a number of genres in popular music beginning today in the late 1960s.

Some are calling this month Zeptember, but I'll resist that, and although it wasn't the inspiration for today's show, it did make me smile!

shows.title: The 27 Club show!
shows.description: The 27 Club in popular culture is a group of well known musicians, artists, or actors who died at age 27. I've been familiar enough with the phenomenon for a while to busk through a conversation in a bar, but I've never really looked deep into it. During yesterday's grunge show, and while playing The Gits and Nirvana, I was inspired to see if I could pull a coherent playlist together containing 27 artists from the beginning of its observation to present day who all died at 27. It aired live at 2PM🗽7PM 🇬🇧 on August 27th.

tracks.title: Ya Got Trouble In River City
Blue Moon

shows.description: A chronological deeper dive into some of the music that made 1985 sound like 1985. I was 5, and was just starting to LOVE music. I remember many of these from that time, and have purposefully skipped some of the more obvious or overplayed ones, in favour of the sounds that reside in the darkest depths of your subconscious ear. "If my calculations are correct, when this baby hits eighty-eight miles per hour... you're going to *hear some serious shit!"

shows.title: The 1990s hip-hop show!
shows.description: East Coast, West Coast, gangsta rap, horrorcore, pop, and even comedy hip hop - these are the genres of tonight's show. This is all rather a guilty pleasure of mine, but firmly an influence in my musical formative years of around 13 to 15. Exceptional beats, brilliantly selected samples, and rapping that quite possibly has been unmatched ever since. There's a reason this era is considered the golden age of hip-hop! Make sure you've got the bass to handle this one!

shows.title: The pre-grunge, early 90s, and Indigo Down EP launch show!
shows.description: To coincide with the release of Indigo Down's new EP - Still Alive, today's show is an excursion into some harder rock from the pre-grunge early 90s, when bands still knew how to play and have a good time doing it! A little sleaze, a little glam, a little hard rock - all with a sprinkle of power pop sensibility, interspersed with Indigo Down's first new material in 16 years! Warm up your vocals and stretch out your hamstrings because this is some high singing, high kicking rock to worry your neighbours with!

shows.title: The "The" bands show!
shows.description: About 30 years ago there was a tiny article in a music magazine, or in the music section of one of the British newspapers, that talked about the trends in band names from really early on in the 1950s until (at that time) present day 1990s. I didn't keep the clipping, but I thought it was very astute, particularly how these trends were recycled and revisited by bands throughout the decades. Today's show is all bands that have "The" at the beginning. A dumb idea, but a really fun show!

The Man Who Would Be King

shows.title: The last fifteen years or so of indie/alt rock show!
shows.description: Somewhere around 2004 there was a subtle shift in indie music and everything seemingly stepped up a gear and started falling more into place (with my taste). Oasis were becoming caricatures of themselves, and instead of bands trying to sound like them, there was a new post-punk influence creeping into the sound, and music started to become a little freer, a little more urgent and aggressive, and not to mention a little more tongue in cheek. I like it!

Pieces Of The People We Love
Why'd You Only Call Me When You're High?

shows.title: The 1990s progressive rock show!
shows.description: Slipping into something a little more comfortable, today's show was a meander through 1990s progressive rock, year by year. I love the epics, I love the weirdness, I love how challenging it all was and still is, and I like being able to reflect on it all now a little more objectively and see where it all fits into the larger musical picture. I hope you enjoy it too!

shows.title: The ska, rocksteady, reggae, 2 tone, ska-punk show!
shows.description: I knew where I wanted to end up today, so I worked in reverse! I was really in the mood for some 2 tone and ska-punk, so I backed way up to play through some of the origins of the genre in Jamaica with ska, rocksteady and reggae before embarking on the trip to Coventry and then to the East and West coasts of the US. Starting off pretty laid back, the show builds throughout and you'll be pogo-ing and skanking right until the end as long as you've appropriately stretched first. I certainly discovered exactly how bouncy my chair is 😎

shows.title: The nineties and naughties international indie alternative show!
shows.description: I keep wondering why there wasn't more crossover with less mainstream non-poppy music of the 90s and 00s between the UK and the US. America had a superb alternative scene in the late 90s and the UK had a great indie scene too, but it seems that they're rarely known by each other's audience. Today's show is roughly split in two - the first hour focusing on the US, and the second the UK. Grab your bootcut jeans, let's go!

shows.title: The new, new music show!
shows.description: Normally scheduled for a Tuesday, today's new music show is a little different, but mainly behind the scenes in constructing the playlist and promoting it. Instead of playlisting the show immediately after I wake up, I listened a little more casually to music throughout the day and picked out tracks for the first hour that jumped out at me. The second half was put together more traditionally, but none of this matters to you! Most importantly I wanted to go back to a more easier going show, less focused on the promotion and more on the music and the experience. I had a lot of fun and made some new friends too! Hope you enjoy it! Squirrel flower.

shows.title: The throwback Thursday 50 Year flashback show!
shows.description: 1970 and 1971 - inspired by an article I read on Tidal about The Rolling Stones' Sticky Fingers album turning fifty, I decided to take a wander through the musical landscape of the time and see how it sat. Post Woodstock, post Altamont, and as Vietnam became increasingly unpopular, how did that affect the music? It apparently didn't affect the members of The Beatles too much as they were mainly focused on being mad at each other!

shows.title: The Adrian Andrews 60s & 70s soul and motown show!
shows.description: Adrian says: "I have so many great tunes in my ‘memory chest’ I had to produce a further mix of solely Soul and Motown." Today's show is a play-through of upbeat danceable soul tracks from the early 60s into the late 70s - a perfect antidote to an overcast and rainy day!

shows.title: The yacht (canoe) rock show!
shows.description: Inspired by Dave and Craig's canoeing excursion on the Medway, I thought it would be nice to have some yacht rock to incongruously accompany them. As it turns out, it was a beautiful day everywhere and I ended up getting to enjoy a run along the Thames with Katherine, a BBQ in Hastings with the family, some ballet in the kitchen in Cheddar with Caroling, and the general feeling that all is right and sunny in the world! Thanks everyone :)

tracks.title: The Things We Do For Love
Just the Two of Us (feat. Bill Withers)
Stuck In The Middle With You
Back In The High Life Again

shows.title: The 21st century (the first 10 years) rock show!
shows.description: Solid well produced, confident, fun, loud, amusing music from the first ten years of the 2000s. A little heavy, a little dark, a little upbeat, a little emo, a little virtuosic, a little pop, and a little punk - I love this era of music. Pour yourself a drink, finish it, pour another, turn it up, sing along and catapult yourself to the early 00s. See you there (with bootcut low rise jeans on)!

shows.title: The early 70s art/progressive/psychedelic/folk rock show!
shows.description: 1973 and 1974 are the sweet spots this evening. Starting off with some Barclay James Harvest, I always find myself wanting to extend and explore that ultra-mellow, super-smooth long form gentle progressive sound of theirs. Tonight was a meander through some albums I was mostly unfamiliar with from artists that I'm not. Not too much of any of the aforementioned genres, but a sprinkle of each to season your ears.

shows.title: The 80s soul, rock 'n roll show!
shows.description: Hugely inspired by the Tina Turner documentary "Tina!" on HBO Max (Sky Documentaries in the UK), I wanted to try to make up for underrating and under representing Tina Turner on the show so far. The documentary was a tough watch, but contained so much phenomenal footage of someone I now consider to be one of the greatest voices, and performers of all time. The 80s were a tricky time for a "sound"  - so much stuff was overproduced and the sense of people recording together was lost a little as digital multi-tracking reduced the need to get things right in fewer takes. With that said though, the 80s sound is also really great, so I wanted to play-through some contemporaries of the era and just enjoy the music.

tracks.title: She's A Bad Mama Jama (She's Built, She's Stacked)

shows.title: The most overlooked folk-rock LPs of the 1960s show!
shows.description: First thing I read this morning was a Rolling Stone article on Richard Thompson's new memoir Beeswing: Losing My Way and Finding My Voice. It tells a sad story of the fatal 1969 crash that killed the band's drummer Martin Lamble, and Thompson's girlfriend at the time Jeannie Franklin. The song I'll Keep It With Mine was played at Lamble's funeral. From here, I wanted to get into some of the deeper cuts of the folk-rock genre and found a superb article written by Richie Unterberger for Record Collector magazine in 2005. I played through some of the artists and built a playlist from here, and the show quickly evolved into a read-through of this article to accompany the selection of songs I had made. All credit to Richie Unterberger for this one!

tracks.title: There Must Be A Someone (I Can Turn To)

shows.title: The hard-rock, blues-rock, groove-rock, funk-rock show!
shows.description:
Slammin' Gladys released their new album Two yesterday and I listened to it so much I didn't do a show. I wanted to represent the music in a way that didn't just lazily tie it to the late wave of 80s rock bands washed away by the tsunami of grunge. Today's show is a play-through of that kind of blues-groove guitar driven music that hits hard and gets you air drumming, strutting, strumming, and singing along to the swagger.

*Also, to correct a misstatement I made in this show speaking about Richie Kotzen and his time with the band Poison. He did not have sex with the drummer and get fired. He had sex with the drummer's wife and got fired. An important distinction! ;)

tracks.title: How Am I Supposed to Write a Luv Song?

shows.title: The supergroups show!
shows.description: I love a supergroup. I mention it every time I play one, and I keep promising myself that I'll do a show about them! As it turns out, there are more than I even realised and so this show is just part one of what may be a three part show. There's something somehow slicker about a supergroup. Perhaps it's less pressure, perhaps it's more, but either way the players seem out to prove something and that's fine with me! Starting in 1960, this first show takes us up to 1977. More to come!

shows.title: The perfect rocky Friday night getting ready show!
shows.description: I LOVE The Struts' new album Strange Days, and in particular the track Another Hit of Showmanship, and I'm always looking for a way to carry on that rocky, punchy, fun and funky vibe throughout a whole show. Since doing the new music shows on Tuesdays I've discovered so much new music and really caught up with what I've been missing out on over the past few years. So starting with The Struts, I began to build the playlist and to my great joy and amusement all the tracks I was picking were released in the last year, and many of the artists I've played on new music shows over the last 9 months or so. I pictured myself leaving work, heading to the local bar, loading the juke box up and sinking several strong beers to shake off the week. Cheers!

shows.title: The super, super, funky show!
shows.description: All credit for the playlist for today's show (apart from the last three songs) goes to Phil "Dr. Philphy" Edwards and his longtime friend and bandmate Steve Chandra Savale - currently of Asian Dub Foundation. Phil and Steve's history has been told a little bit on earlier shows, but Steve's love for funk, and deep cuts from the funk canon (nice job on the homonym English language!) is ready to take you on a musical voyage. There are some SERIOUSLY funky tracks on here so strap in, screw your wig on tight, and turn it up!

shows.title: The late 60s/early 70s British(ish) blues show!
shows.description: "Less shredding, more blues" was the direction received from my Dad to inform this show 🤣, along with a performance of Sugar Mama by Taste. From here I created a playlist of slower, more obscure, almost exclusively British blues tracks (genre not origin of course!), with a few era appropriate and vibe appropriate American bands in compliment! Sit back, unplug, pour yourself a whiskey, gin, cup of tea, or red wine, and sink back into the smooth, sultry, sound of these slow blues tracks.

tracks.title: Sitting On Top Of The World

shows.title: The United States musical travelogue show!
shows.description: Today's show was an alphabetical, autobiographical travelogue through the states I've lived in and visited. The rules were the songs had to have the State name in them, and for places I've lived I went a little deeper with some more songs with more geographical and biographical detail. shows.title: The Steve Lillywhite show!
shows.description: Finally getting a chance to have a play-through of some of Steve Lillywhite's work. Punchy, punky, rocky, funky, slick, sparkling and sweet! Steve Lillywhite's career began in the early 1970s where he was a tape operator for Polygram. He was soon producing and contributing to some of the most well known and successful music of the following decades and continues to produce today having been awarded six Grammy awards and a CBE!

shows.title: The synth-poppy, new-wavey, art-rocky, pop show!
shows.description: Matching the vibe that the rainy weather has delivered this morning, today's show plays through some of the more melancholy music of the 80s pop canon, before manoeuvring into some more upbeat pop-rock to close out. A little bit escapist, a little bit introspective, but plenty to sing along or dance to too. Everything is going to be ok.

tracks.title: The Sun Always Shines on T.V.
If You Leave - From "Pretty In Pink”
Don't Leave Me This Way (with Sarah Jane Morris)
Don't It Make You Feel Good?

shows.title: The simply Soulful Saturday sixties show!
shows.description: It's been a few weeks without some real Soul on the show, and that felt like too long! Today's show is more about the Soul vibe than a specific story about STAX, Motown, or even Northern Soul. Nothing too academic, just great songs moving through a number of vibes - upbeat, funky, danceable, slow, smooth and always soulful.

shows.title: The (mostly) 70s rock, funk and pop show!
shows.description: Beginning yesterday with the assertion that Vivaldi is the Bryan Adams of Classical music, I entered into a conversation with Giles who made a strong case for it being Robert Palmer instead. Today's show begins with a Robert Palmer track and walks an at times funky, rocky and poppy road, but doesn't perhaps complete the conversation about Vivaldi. What do you think?

tracks.title: Thank You (Falettinme Be Mice Elf Agin)

shows.title: The blues rocky, power-poppy, post-punky, new wavey solid Sunday show!
shows.description: Sunday, November 29th, 2020 - the blues rocky, power-poppy, post-punky, new wavey solid Sunday tunes show! Inspired by the Glastonbury performance of Can't You Hear Me Knocking by The Rolling Stones, today's show starts out with a riff and a vibe, and moves through a number of genres that you can let envelop you. From power bass lines to thundering (yet subtle) drums, and epic vocal performances, this is a show for a glass or two of wine and a roast dinner!

tracks.title: De Do Do Do, De Da Da Da
Tunnel of Love (Intro: The Carousel Waltz)
Diamonds on the Soles of Her Shoes

shows.title: The bluesy Tuesday show!
shows.description: With a little rain creeping in to really seal the end of summer in California, today felt like the right day to play some blues. John Mayall, Eric Clapton, Peter Green, Taj Mahal, and Buddy Guy are a few of the artists featured, inspired by a recommendation from my Dad to play the Jeff Beck track Morning Dew.

shows.title: The Carol Kaye show!
shows.description: Carol Kaye is one of the most prolific recorded bass guitarists in rock and pop music, playing on an estimated 10,000 recordings in a career spanning over 50 years. She features heavily in the 2008 documentary The Wrecking Crew, and she is very likely the bass player that you never knew you knew. Today's show is a play-through of some of the contributions that she has made as a musician to popular music throughout the decades.

shows.title: The Eddie Van Halen show!
shows.description: I found myself as shocked and saddened as many guitarists, and music lovers seemed to be at the news that Eddie Van Halen died yesterday. Today's show was an insight into his influences and an example of his style, based on an article I read about him in Rolling Stone from a few years ago. Starting right at the beginning with Les Paul, speaking to his admiration for Eric Clapton, and gathering together all of the ingredients that came together to make him the musician he was.

shows.title: The 80s/90s rock show!
shows.description: I don't imagine that there were many people that had a dream about Enuff Z'Nuff last night, but I did, and I was listening to a tape of their album Strength. That was all the inspiration I needed for today's show when I woke up, but I thought I'd explore some more un-listened (for me) territory within this genre and these years. Nothing too obscure, and it was a great way for me to shake off the work week. Grab your cowboy boots. Let's rock!

shows.title: The piano in rock and pop show!
shows.description: I just finished Ben Folds' autobiography "A Dream About Lightning Bugs: A Life of Music and Cheap Lessons" and it was superb! Ben Folds has been a favourite artist of mine since the first album, and although I can't just do a Ben Folds show (sadly), I wanted to try out a show where piano is featured in all of the songs. Upbeat, fun, a little irreverent at times, and very Ben Folds-y. Today's show proves that pianos rock!

shows.title: The Nile Rodgers show Pt. 2!
shows.description: I've been getting deep into the Nile Rodgers autobiography Le Freak, and it's fantastic! It's a brilliant snapshot of New York in the 60s, 70s, and 80s, with enough detail to jog my memory of living there, and inspire me to add a few new places to explore and walk amongst the ghosts of music history next time I'm there. Nile Rodgers has written, composed, produced, played (and been sampled on) some of the best music over the last five decades, and some of my all time favourite tracks. He's a true pop music superstar. Starting off with some late 60s and early 70s (non Nile Rodgers) tracks that have been playing in my head over the past week, today's show takes a wander through the music that Nile Rodgers has created over the first three decades of his career.

shows.title: The Tamarin time machine birthday show!
shows.description: I found an old set list from a band I was in around 2000-2002 called Tamarin. It was a Boxing Day (the day after Christmas) show, and at that time we were playing 3 or 4 times a week as a tiny power-duo. There's some good stuff on the setlist, and great memories hearing it back again. A little bit self-indulgent, but it is my birthday :) (These are the originals, not the covers we did!)

shows.title: The selections from 68 & 69 show!
shows.description: I just started watching the documentary "Woodstock: 3 Days of Peace & Music." Spoiler alert: It's excellent! In a similar way to how I felt affected by the documentary Laurel Canyon, I found it humanised an event that has been elevated to such a level that made it feel inaccessible in some ways. For today's show I wanted to listen to and explore what was happening in rock music around the time of Woodstock, and consider what music may have been playing on the tape decks of the cars of the people that travelled there.

tracks.title: Morning Sunrise (Live In White Lake, N.Y. 1/18/69)
The Old Man's Back Again (Dedicated To The Neo-Stalinist Regime)
I Love You More Than You'll Ever Know

shows.title: The late 80s, early 90s rock show!
shows.description: This is the one I've been waiting for, but after getting into some "deeper cuts" with yesterday's show, and waking up with Aerosmith's Blind Man stuck in my head, I took a similar approach and didn't go for the obvious tracks. Lots of hair, lots of 'tude, a couple of ballads, and a sprinkling of innuendo, I really enjoyed this show. This is the music I grew up on!

This is the second part of the story of being 16 years old in England in 1980 and growing up through the decade with Post-Punk, New Wave and John Peel, picking up in 1985 and closing out the decade.

shows.title: The Steve Cropper show!
shows.description: As writer, musician, producer, and label owner, Steve Cropper has created some of the most well-known and well-loved music from the 1960s onwards. He's a Memphis legend, and while I lived there, I worked out of the same recording studio he owned after he left STAX – Trans-Maximus Records (TMI). Now owned by Playhouse on the Square, the building is still rich with creativity, and during my time there, we used the building for writing and recording music for numerous shows, and other projects.

shows.title: The soundbathing show!
shows.description: British DJ and TV presenter Johnny Vaughan coined the term "soundbathing" on his Radio X show, and I think it's such a perfect description for sinking into a song, and letting it all wash over you. Today's show should allow you to sit back, sink into your chair, turn the music up, and escape the world for a couple of hours. Oh, and there's some gin recipes in there too!

shows.title: The show inspired by Dylan's famous "Judas!" gig!
shows.description: 54 years ago today, at the Manchester Free Trade Hall, before the final song of the night, an audience member yelled "Judas!" The rest is History. I played some songs from the few years before that event, and found a musical seam that brought us up to date with "new" music from the last 20 years.
